cases.title: ### Enterprise Product Organization
cases.subtitle: *Aligning 12 product teams to 4 strategic themes*
cases.description: A SaaS company with 12 product teams was struggling with strategic alignment. Leadership defined 4 strategic themes (Customer Growth, Platform Scalability, Revenue Expansion, Security & Compliance) but had no visibility into which teams were contributing to each theme or when.
cases.solution: With two-level roadmaps: Leadership created an organizational roadmap with the 4 themes and defined quarterly intervals with investment targets (30% Customer Growth, 25% Scalability, 25% Revenue, 20% Security). Each product team created roadmaps linking their objectives to organizational themes. Leadership now sees a real-time view of all 12 teams' work organized by theme and quarter.
results: **Quarterly planning meetings reduced from 8 hours to 2 hours**

cases.title: ### Fast-Growing Startup
cases.subtitle: *Scaling from 1 to 5 product teams without losing focus*
cases.description: A Series B startup grew from 1 product team to 5 in 6 months. Their roadmap was a Google Sheet that quickly became unmaintainable. Different teams planned in different tools, timelines conflicted, and the CEO lost visibility into what was actually getting built.
cases.solution: With two-level roadmaps: The CPO defined 3 strategic themes (Product-Market Fit, Enterprise Readiness, Platform Foundation) on an organizational roadmap with 6-week release cycles. Each new product team created their roadmap aligned to these themes and intervals. The CEO can now filter by theme to see cross-team progress or by team to see individual execution.
results: **Scaled from 1 to 5 teams without planning chaos**
**CEO visibility into all work on a single screen**
**New teams onboard to planning process in under 1 hour**
**Strategic themes guide hiring and resource allocation decisions**

cases.title: ### Platform Company
cases.subtitle: *Coordinating product and platform team dependencies*
cases.description: A platform company had 4 product teams and 2 platform teams (API, Infrastructure). Product teams would plan features that depended on platform work, but platform teams had no visibility into these dependencies. Launches kept slipping because platform work wasn't scheduled.
cases.solution: With two-level roadmaps: Product and platform teams all plan on the same organizational timeline. When a product team drags an objective requiring new API endpoints onto Q2, they tag it with dependencies. Platform team sees this in their roadmap view, schedules the API work in Q1. Dependencies are visible, timelines coordinate automatically.
results: **Zero launch delays due to platform dependencies in 6 months**
**Platform team roadmap driven by actual product needs**
**Product teams can see platform capacity before committing**

questions.question: ### Do I have to use both organizational and product roadmaps?
questions.answer: No. You can start with just product roadmaps if you're a single-team company or early-stage startup. Add the organizational layer when you have multiple teams that need strategic alignment. The system works at either level independently.

questions.question: ### What if our organization doesn't think in "themes"?
questions.answer: Themes are flexible‚Äîcall them strategic pillars, bets, focus areas, or anything that makes sense for your organization. The concept is simply "what are the top-level categories we organize work around?" Most organizations already have these, even if they're currently living in slide decks.

questions.question: ### How do intervals/timeboxes work?
questions.answer: You define intervals with start and end dates at the organizational level (e.g., Q1 2025: Jan 1 - Mar 31, Q2 2025: Apr 1 - Jun 30). Product roadmaps inherit these intervals. You can also create hierarchical intervals (e.g., quarters that contain sprints). Intervals are flexible‚Äîuse whatever timeline structure your organization follows.

questions.question: ### Can we change the roadmap structure mid-year?
questions.answer: Absolutely. Roadmaps are living documents. Add/remove themes, adjust interval dates, move work items between timeboxes‚Äîall with drag-and-drop or simple edits. Changes sync in real-time. Your roadmap adapts as your strategy evolves.

questions.question: ### How does this integrate with our backlog?
questions.answer: The roadmap includes a collapsible backlog panel showing unscheduled (orphan) work items‚Äîepics, features, and objectives that aren't yet on the timeline. Drag items from the backlog onto intervals when you're ready to schedule them. Items automatically return to the backlog if removed from intervals.

questions.question: ### What's the difference between roadmap and strategy board?
questions.answer: Strategy Board is for validating what to build (objectives ‚Üí opportunities ‚Üí solutions ‚Üí experiments). Roadmap is for scheduling when to build it (organizing validated work on a timeline). They integrate: validated strategy items flow into roadmap objectives. Think of Strategy Board as the 'why' and Roadmap as the 'when.'

questions.question: ### Can external stakeholders view our roadmap?
questions.answer: Yes. You can share roadmap views with stakeholders. Export as PDF or JPEG for presentations. Control what's visible via filters (e.g., show only customer-facing work, hide internal platform items). Share links to specific theme or product roadmap views.

questions.question: ### How many product roadmaps can we have?
questions.answer: Unlimited. Each product, initiative, or team can have their own roadmap. All product roadmaps can align to the same organizational roadmap and themes. This lets each team plan independently while maintaining strategic alignment.
